reviewText:
Before I begin: I'm not talking about plot at all as it's a quirky, weird experience with a pretty interesting story.

The easiest way I can describe this game is 'Clue meets Professor Layton'. Everything about this title is charming - the dialogue is humorous and moves the storylines along, the puzzles require a bit of dumb luck but once you dig through the game and find them all the setting feels pretty robust.

The gameplay is split into two components: 'Investigation' and Conversing. Through investigating the setting and speaking to characters who inhabit the space with you, you gain mastery and experience on a handful of intersecting plotlines. The conversing 'mini-game' is almost like playing three games of Rock-Paper-Scissors at once. Each step you take towards defeating your opponent results in a different 'stat' losing some of it's power. These different tiers are set atop an actual game of R-P-S... so starting out it seems more complicated than it is.

The only negative comment I'd say regarding this fun game is because of how the gameplay is configured there is quite a bit of repetition both in investigating, purchasing items, and winning conversations. This is relatively minor due to the short length of the title (and I was playing to 100%, which I hit around 10 hours).

It's pretty remarkable for how polished this game is in it's current state given the small staff. I hope we see more in this Tale of Last Words!

The full (German) review can be found here: http://www.jack-reviews.com/2015/05/last-word-rpg-maker-review.html

Last Word is a mixture of adventure and rpg and takes place in a world where words are mightier than any weapon. And that's why the guests of professor Chet Chatters find themselves in a pickle. He's created a machine that enables him to win every conversation, which allows him to control the minds of others as if they were hypnotized.

Whitty Gawship, a photographer who doesn't fit in with the rest of the crowd, is the only one who might be able to overcome the machine's influence and escape the professor's clutches. But first she has to get better at conversations, as the battle system consists of each opponent flinging words at each other.

It seems simple at first, until you aquire a couple of skills to make it more strategic.
You gather power, convert it into tact, then smash through your opponent's defenses to get the last word.
To do that, you have three types of conversations to choose from, all with different inflections. So why not choose the most powerful every time? Because there's also a rock-paper-scissor-element that you need to take into account. Choose the one that defeats your opponent's previous tone and he will lose composure, which makes aggressive conversations all the more powerful.

It's an interesting concept, but the ressource gathering feels a bit exhausting at times. It would have been fine if there were only a handful of battles, but I must have done them dozens of times to get as much as possible out of the game. Finding every secret can alleviate it somewhat, however. And if you like the system, there are additional challenges to choose from. They're far from impossible, but it took me a couple of tries.

Is the story worth it at least? If you like that kind of setting and lots of dialogue, certainly. Especially if you try to uncover the entire mystery. It's not going to blow your mind, but it's nice enough.

What I didn't particularly like was the design of the character sprites. There's no real reason for them to be colored blobs walking through an otherwise well designed world. Having them wear color-coded outfits would have been fine.

All in all, a nice rpg-maker game that I would certainly recommend. It might not stay with you for long, but it's good enough to spent about 5 hours with.

I've played a lot of RPGs in my time, but I've never played one like Last Word. It's always nice to see an RPG use an unusual setting, and one in which veteran military linguists are revered as paragons of citizenry is a rare thing indeed. The custom battle system uses a rock-paper-scissors element, but as part of a resource-based system that makes choosing to use or ignore the rock-paper-scissors elements on a given turn an important decision in both the short and mid- to long-term. It's not a tens-of-hours affair, but it does take several hours, and you spend the whole time learning new things about the characters and the world they live in. Last Word is a brilliant game that is set on the borders on reality and surrealism, in a world where the logic of power is pinned down to the last word.

This game is very unique in its own ways, the battle system is replaced with discourse (debating) and whole groups of well-minded individuals can be captured through words, so long as they get the last word in. The voice acting is very minimal, but that just adds to the overall feeling of the game, instead of full on sentences being spoken, you will hear scoff and sighs, giving more character to the characters.

Although Last Word has a serious air to it with the discourse and the attire, the game is far from serious. There are many little funny things in the game, such as arguing with a cat and even the characters names.

I would recommend Last Word to anyone who wants to experience a game that is different from the generic RPGs that are churned forth from the gaming system, and to anyone else who just wants to play a good game with a great plot.

reviewText:
A Lesson in Minimalism

Pros
-Short, casual game with depth
-Interesting complicated AND simple characters: By the end you'll likely get to know everyone
-Intriquing setting
-Combat mechanics: start out simple, but get deep
+Abilities actually add to the depth of combat
-Text heavy adventure: Great for those who like some reading in their video games
-Alternative endings that can be discovered through reloads (rather than starting from the beginning).
-Minimalistic environment: Story takes place in one-two indoor settings, but there is plenty to discover (mostly through dialogue)

Cons
-The AI cannot exploit the combat system fully. Leaving players without challenge towards the end of the game.
-Text heavy adventure: Terrible for those who don't like to read in their vijeo games
-Really short (but worth it).

This short little game is impressive and I feel like it did everything right. I'm more of ahardcore gamer myself, I love things like Dwarf Fortress, FTL, or anything that'll give me a bit of a challenge. I'm also a sucker for a good story though, and I like anything that'll make me start wrapping my brain around it. This game is heavily story driven with a mixture of clue and RPGness. And everything works together towards the goal of not only telling the story, but creating a believable setting.

While others have stated that the game doesn't properly explain the 'Whys' of the setting (why getting the last word has power in this world), the game does take the time to nod at this and pretty much say that the residents of this world don't know, and in turn, we the audience won't know (though maybe it is discoverable in an alternate ending)? Whatever the case may be the developers are excellent writers. We have a variety of characters, some are complicated and will be developed over the course of the game (IE, the servant and Seymore) while others are simple and 'translucent.' What you see is what you get, but they also have their own sort of depth (their dreams, their hopes, etc). Even the most unlikable characters will have redeemable qualities and will make some common cause with the protagonist. In the end, not all characters need to be deep complicated messes, and not all mysteries will necessarily be 'solved.'

And the combat mechanics plus unlockable abilities meant that as soon as you started to get into the swing of things you would start delving deeper into this elegantly simple but complicated system. The AI has trouble properly exploiting this, but it 'knows' enough to provide a challenge over the course of the game. By the end I was consistently winning and I would have been bored if it dragged on much longer. As it is, just enough challenge was coded in to last me until I reached the first ending.

Which was fine because in a way this is a game about discovery and exploration, most of which is buried in dialogue. If you do get this game I recommend you save between chapters (right before the next chapter) in different slots. This way you can return to an old chapter to review certain conversations, which might advance some story elements towards the end of the game.

Again, if you like to read AND play video games, this game is likely for you. Hopefully you'll enjoy it as much as I did.

You can learn about what is Last Word in other reviews, so I'll make this quick.

Last Word reminds me of all those Nintendo DS games like Ace Attorney or Ghost Trick. Why? Well, it's colourful, rather slow-paced, story-centered and there's a gameplay gimmick around which the game revolves. AA had interrogations, Ghost Trick - messing around with objects. Last Word has discourses. They pretty much substitute the battle systems you could see in any Japanese (or Japanese-styled) RPG.

To put it simply, Last Word is a short, story-based fusion of a jRPG and an adventure game with discourses instead of battles, good music, pretty visuals, interesting characters and some humour now and then. There are even two endings and some additional stuff to do/collect.

reviewText:
TLDR; Game rates an 8 out of 10 as a fun, story-driven romp with clever mechanics.

This, is a dramatically clever take on rpgs, crossed with tug-of-war. And it works absurdly well! The idea to use conversation as a combat mechanic is quite well done, and the skills and abilities, while powerful, never feel so overwhelming that the game becomes unbalanced - in much the way that old rpgs expected a player to grind up to max level to survive the final boss, a player needs to reach almost the pinnacle of conversational acumen to stand against the verbal hail of the last boss (and the secret boss). Further, this rarely, if ever, hits the point of formula - you cannot rinse and repeat every opponent, and more than a little thought is required to reach victory every time. More importantly, this game is fairly short - hitting the pinnacle takes only a few hours, tops - the grind is barely noticable. I finished my first run in ~8 hours, and that was because I was trying to get 100% completion.

The writing is the gem in this piece, and it comes through very well. In originality, if nothing else, the script nails its goals precisely, and with a lot of panache. It's like the most civil attempt to slaughter a dinner party by cutting wit alone. The sound effects are also pretty good, and there is some minor voice acting (You too will want to slug Seymour by the end!) which adds to the experience. Replay value is a little limited - there are some clear points where you will know you missed something, and the game is short enough that such hints will tempt you into a replay, but I only see someone going after 2 or 3 rounds of it initially. The mechanics and skill to win may see you firing up the game again every once in a while (the end boss fights are really quite amusing), so save just before the end, but otherwise? meh.

The visuals are quite simple (but pretty stylish, all the same), and the exploration, while extensive (there are almost no details that won't matter at some point), is by no means large (effectively, the game takes place in 4 rooms, with exploration being limited to using various topics to unlock different reactions).

The music is pretty good, if not spectacular.

TLDR; Game rates an 8 out of 10 as a fun, story driven romp with clever mechanics.

reviewText:
A very amusing game, with charming and stylish art, story, and sound design.

It looks like your typical turn based rpg, that's set inside a single mansion, but it's not quite what you expect.

Basically there's two parts of the gameplay. The first part is investigating topics by talking to other guests that's locked in the mansion with you. You investigate and gather informations about key topics and you use it to move the story forward.

The second part, that is the meat of the game, is the discourse, the battle system. In this game, conversation is serious business, and having the last word can give you literal domination toward your discourse partner.

It's basically one-on-one turn-based rpg battle. But you don't take turn stabbing each others with swords of course. You take turn in abstract discussions, and try to gain the last word.

You have choices on what to do. You throw disruptive remark to mostly gain power. You can throw submissive remark to trade your power with tact, and finally you can throw agressive remark to actually move the conversation toward your end. Other than that there are things you must consider, like your and your opponent's composure, which is basically your defenses, the tone of conversation (tones have paper-rock-scissors relationship, and they have different effects or can destroy your opponent's composure), and of course various personal skills everyone have.

Basically, a pretty charming and stylistic twist on typical turn-based rpg.

Suspect in the happenings of the evening are the various movers and shakers of the government, military and other important individuals, but among them all stands a strange outlier, yourself.  In the role of Whitty Gawship the peculiarities of the evening are secondary to just why you've been invited to these proceedings while having no such lofty status.

reviewText:
Pretty fun little RPG-with-a-twist.

The concept
Combat is replaced by 'discourse' so you win by getting the upper hand in a battle of wits and words. It's worth pointing out though that you're trading verbal blows in a sort of abstract fashion - you don't use actual dialogue in battle.
The game is relatively short for an RPG (ignore my playtime, I left it running for overnight and longer so I could get all the steam cards!) and set in a mansion over the course of one evening. Apart from the discourse, you'll be talking to the same few characters repeatedly about different subjects, allowing you to unlock new topics based on what you find out. There's a few basic puzzles and some stuff to collect as the plot unfolds.

Pros
+ Innovative and fun concept which feels cohesive - the entire game is themed on words, right down to the character names.
+ Decent enough story, though the one-setting-one-evening nature of the game is pretty limiting
+ The verbal combat is fun once you know what you're doing
+ Art style is simple but engaging
+ Music is good - reminded me a little of To the Moon in places

Cons
- Really needs some options - pretty much the only options you get are how often the characters make little introductory sounds, and what music plays. No resolution options, for example, or volume bars. (That I could find, anyway!) Mouse support would be nice as well!
- Some of the in game descriptions of how things like the tone wheel work are a little ambiguous, in my opinion. Once you 'get it' though you should be fine in nearly every combat, particularly if you don't mind doing a bit of grinding early on. I have to admit the first couple of battles were a little bit 'what on earth?!!'
- Not exactly a con, but explore *everything* before you talk to anyone with a lock above their heads (which moves the story on). I didn't realise and missed a couple of things that then became inaccessible, so it's no longer possible for me to 100% the game unless I replay everything (which I'm not really inclined to do). My fault for not realising until I'd already saved over my progress really...!
- My main issue with this game is the lack of content and variety in settings and characters. There are very few people to battle with and you only have a few rooms to explore in the house. Talking to the same characters over and over gets a little repetitive.

Overall
All in all it was an enjoyable experience and for the price I can forgive the limited content. It would be great to see a sequel that's more fleshed out with more people and places as I think there's a lot more that can be done with the idea. I'd recommend giving this one a go though for an evening's worth of intelluctually-themed intrigue.

reviewText:
This was a fairly fun game, with a unique premise, though it does tend to get a bit repetitive.  Pretty much the entirety of the game play outside of battles consists of walking back and forth within the same couple of rooms, talking to each character over and over until you've exhausted all conversation topics trying to trigger the next story event, and then doing the same thing again and again once you do.

Fortunately, the actual combat portions of the game, which is probably the larger chunk of the game, is pretty good.  This is a game where the battle system actually gets better the further you progress.  While at first it may seem a bit random and confusing, as you continue to level up and gain new skills it becomes considerably more strategic and satisfying, as your options in battle increase quite a bit.

The game is on the short side; I was able to get both endings in just over five hours, and I imagine it would be fairly similar for everyone else.  And the only real replay value comes in the form of starting the game over again just to do things that you accidentally locked yourself out of doing the first time (which is annoyingly easy to do).  So, I probably would not recommend getting the game at its full price, as I don't think the amount of content justifies the cost.  However, it is often on sale, and is an overall enjoyable game, so I can recommend picking it up then.

reviewText:
I liked this game a lot more than I thought I would. The battle system is pretty fresh but easy to manipulate once you get the hang of it, and for the length there is a lot of character and plot depth that you can explore. It felt to me somewhat similar to something I might have played on the GBA years ago or even the DS and was a little nostalgic, though that was at least partially because of the graphics.

Cons:
The battle system is a little tricky to learn at first, and complex enough that it's certainly possible to miss one or two elements of it in the tutorial, so if you don't pay close attention you can find yourself floundering some. Also if you don't look at all possible options for interaction you can find yourself lost about what the game wants you to do next at some points, but that tends to be fairly typical for a lot of adventure games.

Pros:
Despite being tricky to pick up, once you understand all the elements of the battle system it becomes fairly easy to use even to defeat characters levels above you once you really get some experience with it. The Upgrade options make for some fun and useful customization to that end, and you don't even need to over-level by obscene amounts to get them all, plus some of them make leveling up pretty quick. You don't need to explore every nook and dialogue option in order to advance if you listen to the suggestions made by characters, but I recommend it if you want to learn everything you can about said characters and the story.

It's a pretty short game; certainly complete-able in an afternoon, but surprisingly satisfying for its length. The hours I have logged for it are the result of multiple playthroughs to get all the achievements... and the secret ending of course. :)
